chapter.title: What is Web:Extend?
chapter.para: Web:Extend is a simple, modern, powerful PHP web framework.

sect1.title: Project history
sect1.para: The initial work on Web:Extend was performed during summer 2005 and focused on automating the creation, handling and validation of web forms. The source from this library went on to become Web:Extend a few months later and saw the addition of many other solutions to automate and simplify the development process of web applications.

After becoming a framework, Web:Extend focused on harnessing the power of the Standard PHP Library to simplify the writing of code. It also changed the error handling to use exceptions everywhere, and made use of autoload to eliminate the need to manually include files.

More recently, the ability to query databases' metadata was added. The scaffolding components were built on this mechanism, allowing developers for example to simply specify a table name to create a fully functional domain model and also to create fully functional forms to interact with this table. In addition all the scaffolding components operate live on the database, meaning that any modification of a table during development is immediately taken into account without requiring the developer's intervention.

sect1.title: Features
sect1.para: Web:Extend focuses on simplicity. Simplicity indicates a state of clarity and straightforwardness. Simple concepts and situations are commonly easier to explain and understand than complicated ones. They allow the developer to become free from hardship, effort and confusion.

Simplicity allows the developer to focus on the requirements of his project rather than on its implementation. The developer can focus on the business logic of his application rather than on technical details, which allows him to deliver a finished product much faster and at lower costs.
To that end, Web:Extend includes the following features:

listitem.para: Live scaffolding using the database metadata

sect1.para: To achieve this quality, Web:Extend has developed various tools, including a unit test suite designed specifically for the framework's needs and a grep engine capable of detecting many inappropriate uses of PHP and the framework.

Another key feature is that Web:Extend does not hesitate to remove or rewrite inadequate experimental code. Experimental code is usually included in a beta release and used by our developers in real projects. Depending on the feedback received, any such code may be removed from the next release. An experimental addition that is too confusing always gets killed or rewritten.

sect1.title: Goals
sect1.para: At this point the Web:Extend core is very stable. The remaining changes planned are relatively small. These include improving support for various configurations and providing developers with better debugging tools.

Work has also begun on an optional extra library distributed with the framework. This library, weexlib, gives a set of functions and templates that can be readily used to speed-up development using the Web:Extend framework.

Further additions will come in the form of addons. We are currently working on addon management functionality that will allow anyone to not only easily install and update addons, but also write and publish them. A publicly available addon repository will be made available at a later stage.

sect1.title: Target audience
sect1.para: Web:Extend is targeted at experienced PHP5 developers. It can be used in many kinds of projects of various sizes and performance requirements. Being an open-source product licensed under the LGPL, it can also be used in commercial solutions as long as the license is respected.

Its most common use will be for web application projects, websites, CMS, and the likes. Web:Extend has the potential to scale to a significant amount of traffic but currently has yet to be used in projects with more than a few hundred hits per second. Additional testing and tweaks are probably required in that domain.

sect1.title: Downloading Web:Extend
sect1.para: Web:Extend can be downloaded from the project's github, either by cloning the repository or by downloading a release tarball.
The current version of the framework can be retrieved using the following command:

By default you will have the latest source available, which is intended for development of the framework and not for production. You can however switch to a release tag by listing the tags available and picking the one you want. From the cloned folder:
sect1.screen: $ git tag -l wee-0.1.0 wee-0.2.0 wee-0.3.0 wee-0.4.0 wee-0.5.0 wee-0.6.0 $ git checkout wee-0.6.0
sect1.para: When using the master branch, make sure to initialize the submodules too:
sect1.screen: $ git submodule init Submodule 'res/blueprint-css' registered for path 'res/blueprint-css' $ git submodule update Initialized empty Git repository in ...
sect1.para: If you can't or don't want to use git, you can simply head over to the project's download page and pick the version you need: http://github.com/essen/wee/downloads.

caution.para: It is highly recommended that you download the latest release as older versions may not contain all the enhancements and are thus not representative of the Web:Extend product today.
Older releases may also not be supported anymore and could contain security vulnerabilities.

sect1.title: The Web:Extend Community
sect1.para: The Web:Extend developers rely on the community's feedback to improve the framework. Any feedback or queries from users is always taken into consideration and is responded to whenever possible.

The Web:Extend developers can be contacted through various channels. We currently have an IRC channel and mailing lists, and can be contacted directly through github either using the issues tracker or by private message. Based on feedback received, a user wiki will also be opened in the near future.
The IRC channel is #webextend on irc.freenode.net. All other community outposts can be found by browsing the project's website available at http://extend.ws.
